instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2485: What is A2485? A2485 is a model number for a 16 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2021 M1 with EMC 3651, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-02100, 820-02382..
definitions.820-02100: What is 820-02100? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A2337: What is A2337? A2337 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2020 M1 with EMC 3598, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-02016..
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP3V3_S2: What is PP3V3_S2? PP3V3_S2 is a typo of PP3V3_S3.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2485</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02100</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-11 issue
threads.message:
Hi,
On this motherboard there was liquid damage.

Pin 6 of UR200 was not connected
Remplace RF242 too.

Now I have 5V 0.02A on the USB C meter with USB C port (cause magsafe charger no light).
Amps goes to 0.16 when pulse.

[SIZE=5][I]Voltage I have :[/I][/SIZE]
[LIST]
[*]LDO of CD3217B12
[LIST]
[*][B]<SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC0_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> [/B]1.5V
[*][B]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC0_LDO</SIGNAL> [/B]3V
[/LIST]
[*][B]<SIGNAL>PPHV_INT0_AONSW</SIGNAL> [/B]5V
[*][B]<SIGNAL>PPVBUS_USBC0</SIGNAL> [/B]5V
[*][COLOR=rgb(0, 0, 0)][B]<SIGNAL>PP3V8_AON</SIGNAL>[/B] 3.8V[/COLOR]
[*][COLOR=rgb(0, 0, 0)][B]<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AON</SIGNAL>[/B] 1.8V[/COLOR]
[/LIST]

[I]I have pulse (see picture attached for timing pulse) on :[/I]
[LIST]
[*][B]<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S2</SIGNAL> [/B]1.8V (seems that <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> shorted it to ground when it's LOW)
[*][B]<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S2</SIGNAL>[/B] [COLOR=rgb(235, 107, 86)]Only 0.6V[/COLOR]
[*][B]<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> [/B]1.2V
[*][B]<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> [/B]1.8V
[/LIST]
I have nothing on :
[LIST]
[*][B][B]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S2SW_USBC01</SIGNAL>[/B][/B]
[*][B][B]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2</SIGNAL>[/B][/B]
[*][B][B]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AON</SIGNAL>[/B][/B]
[/LIST]
I changed the 3 CD3217B12 from M1 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> donor.. Behavior is the same
Nothing is hot at the thermal camera

I am running out of idea, if someone has will send some love :D

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2485</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02100</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-11 issue
threads.message:
There must be something else affected by corrosion.
Check <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> LDOs.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> exact voltage?
It is stable?

Thanks in advance :)

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2485</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02100</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-11 issue
threads.message:
<CHIP>U8100</CHIP>'s VLDO1 (<SIGNAL>3V3_S2</SIGNAL>) must be stable, if <SIGNAL>VIN_LDO1</SIGNAL> is stable (<SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL>).
If not, there may be a problem with <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>, M1 CPU, or other component connected there.
I recommend to try reballing <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> first.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2485</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02100</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-11 issue
threads.message:
Hi,
Successfully reball <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>.
There was not oxydation under these chips
Nothing more, still pulse

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2485</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02100</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-11 issue
threads.message:
Check all seconday power supplies.
Maybe PMUs detect a problem and cycle power.

You may also have problems with M1 CPU.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2485</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02100</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-11 issue
threads.message:
Thanks for your reply, do you have some informations about secondary power supply ?
I work on windows laptop, mac is a bit different ^^
Thanks

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2485</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02100</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-11 issue
threads.message:
Any voltage generated from main power supply using a buck converter.
Same theory applies like on any other laptop.

Look at the coils from the MLB, the ones having a MOSFET connected to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL>; for example L/<TRANSISTOR>Q5800</TRANSISTOR>/20/40.
There may be also power chips which include the MOSFETs; like L/<CHIP>U9400</CHIP>/20, L/<CHIP>U9500</CHIP>, L/UC260, L/UF800.

Many low level voltages are generated from <SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL>; for example the small coils around <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> and <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>.
There you can't find direct short to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL>, but can block the power sequence.
